**Oslo** ^[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)^ (
Norwegian: [\[ˈʊ̂ʂlʊ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Norwegian "Help:IPA/Norwegian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/0/0d/Oslo.ogg/Oslo.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Oslo.ogg "File:Oslo.ogg")^ or [\[ˈʊ̂slʊ, ˈʊ̀ʂlʊ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Norwegian "Help:IPA/Norwegian"); [Southern Sami](/wiki/Southern_Sami_language "Southern Sami language"): *Oslove* ^[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)^) is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and [most populous](/wiki/List_of_towns_and_cities_in_Norway "List of towns and cities in Norway") city of [Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway"). It constitutes both a [county](/wiki/Counties_of_Norway "Counties of Norway") and a [municipality](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Norway "Municipalities of Norway"). The municipality of Oslo had a population of 709,037 in 2022, while the city's greater [urban area](/wiki/Urban_area "Urban area") had a population of 1,064,235 in 2022,^[\[14\]](#cite_note-SSB-2023-14)^ and the [metropolitan area](/wiki/Metropolitan_area "Metropolitan area") had an estimated population of 1,546,706 in 2021.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-regjeringen2010-15)^{#cite_ref-regjeringen2010_15-0}

During the [Viking Age](/wiki/Viking_Age "Viking Age"), the area was part of [Viken](/wiki/Viken_(region) "Viken (region)"). Oslo was founded as a city at the end of the Viking Age in 1040 under the name **Ánslo** , and established as a [*kaupstad*](/wiki/Kjobstad "Kjobstad") or trading place in 1048 by [Harald Hardrada](/wiki/Harald_Hardrada "Harald Hardrada"). The city was elevated to a [bishopric](/wiki/Diocese_of_Oslo "Diocese of Oslo") in 1070 and a capital under [Haakon V of Norway](/wiki/Haakon_V_of_Norway "Haakon V of Norway") around the year 1300. [Personal unions](/wiki/Personal_union "Personal union") with [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") from [1397 to 1523](/wiki/Kalmar_Union "Kalmar Union") and again from [1536 to 1814](/wiki/Denmark%E2%80%93Norway "Denmark–Norway") reduced its influence. After being destroyed by a fire in 1624, during the reign of [King Christian IV](/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark "Christian IV of Denmark"), a new city was built closer to [Akershus Fortress](/wiki/Akershus_Fortress "Akershus Fortress") and named **Christiania** in honour of the king. It became a [municipality](/wiki/List_of_municipalities_of_Norway "List of municipalities of Norway") (*[formannskapsdistrikt](/wiki/Formannskapsdistrikt "Formannskapsdistrikt")* ) on 1 January 1838. The city functioned as the capital of Norway during the 1814--1905 [union between Sweden and Norway](/wiki/Union_between_Sweden_and_Norway "Union between Sweden and Norway"). From 1877, the city's name was spelled **Kristiania** in government usage, a spelling that was adopted by the municipal authorities in 1897, although 'Christiania' was also used. In 1925, the city, after incorporating the village retaining its former name, was [renamed](#1900–present) 'Oslo'. In 1948, Oslo merged with [Aker](/wiki/Aker,_Norway "Aker, Norway"), a municipality which surrounded the capital and which was 27 times larger, thus creating the modern, much larger Oslo municipality.

Oslo is the [economic](/wiki/Economy_of_Norway "Economy of Norway") and [governmental](/wiki/Politics_of_Norway "Politics of Norway") centre of Norway. The city is also a hub of Norwegian trade, banking, industry and shipping. It is an important centre for maritime industries and [maritime trade](/wiki/Maritime_trade "Maritime trade") in Europe. The city is home to many companies within the maritime sector, some of which are among the world's largest shipping companies, shipbrokers and maritime insurance brokers. Oslo is a pilot city of the [Council of Europe](/wiki/Council_of_Europe "Council of Europe") and the [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission") intercultural cities programme.

Oslo is considered a [global city](/wiki/Global_city "Global city") and was ranked "Beta World City" in studies carried out by the Globalization and World Cities Study Group and Network in 2008.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-16)^ It was ranked number one in terms of quality of life among European large cities in the European Cities of the Future 2012 report by *fDi* magazine.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-fdiintelligence.com-17)^ A survey conducted by [ECA International](/wiki/ECA_International "ECA International") in 2011 placed Oslo as the second most expensive city in the world for living expenses after [Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo").^[\[18\]](#cite_note-18)^ In 2013, Oslo tied with the Australian city of [Melbourne](/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne") as the fourth most expensive city in the world, according to the [Economist Intelligence Unit](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit") (EIU)'s Worldwide Cost of Living study.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-19)^ Oslo was ranked as the 24th most liveable city in the world by Monocle magazine.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-20)^{#cite_ref-20}

Oslo's population was increasing at record rates during the early 2000s, making it the fastest growing major [city](/wiki/Metropolitan_area "Metropolitan area") in Europe at the time.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-21)^ This growth stems for the most part from international [immigration](/wiki/Immigration_to_Norway "Immigration to Norway") and related high birth rates, but also from intra-national migration. By 2010 the immigrant population in the city was growing somewhat faster than the [Norwegian](/wiki/Norwegians "Norwegians") population,^[\[22\]](#cite_note-22)^ and in the city proper this had become more than 25% of the total population if the children of immigrant parents were included.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-Immigration-23)^{#cite_ref-Immigration_23-0}  

Urban region {#Urban_region}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Urban region")\]  
See also: [List of boroughs of Oslo](/wiki/List_of_boroughs_of_Oslo "List of boroughs of Oslo")

The municipality of Oslo has a population of 717,710 as of 1 January 2024.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-auto-24)^ The urban area extends far beyond the boundaries of the municipality into the surrounding [county](/wiki/Counties_of_Norway "Counties of Norway") of [Akershus](/wiki/Akershus "Akershus") (municipalities of [Asker](/wiki/Asker "Asker"), [Bærum](/wiki/B%C3%A6rum "Bærum"), [Lillestrøm](/wiki/Lillestr%C3%B8m_Municipality "Lillestrøm Municipality"), [Enebakk](/wiki/Enebakk "Enebakk"), [Rælingen](/wiki/R%C3%A6lingen "Rælingen"), [Lørenskog](/wiki/L%C3%B8renskog "Lørenskog"), [Nittedal](/wiki/Nittedal "Nittedal"), [Gjerdrum](/wiki/Gjerdrum "Gjerdrum"), [Nordre Follo](/wiki/Nordre_Follo "Nordre Follo")); being, to a great degree suburbs of Oslo making up approximately 500,000 of the population of the [greater Oslo region](/wiki/Greater_Oslo_Region "Greater Oslo Region"). The total population of this agglomeration was 1,546,706 in 2023.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-SSB-2023-14)^ The city centre is situated at the end of the [Oslofjord](/wiki/Oslofjord "Oslofjord"), from which point the city sprawls out in three distinct "corridors"---inland north-eastwards, and southwards along both sides of the fjord---which gives the [urbanized area](/wiki/Urban_area "Urban area") a shape reminiscent of an upside-down reclining "Y" (on maps, satellite pictures, or from high above the city).{#cite_ref-SSB-2023_14-1}

To the north and east, wide forested hills (*Marka* ) rise above the city giving the location the shape of a giant [amphitheatre](/wiki/Amphitheatre "Amphitheatre"). The urban [municipality](/wiki/List_of_municipalities_of_Norway "List of municipalities of Norway") (*bykommune* ) of Oslo and county (*[fylke](/wiki/Counties_of_Norway "Counties of Norway")* ) of Oslo are two parts of the same entity, making Oslo the only city in Norway where two administrative levels are integrated. Of Oslo's total area, 130 km^2^ (50 sq mi) is built-up and 9.6 km^2^ (3.7 sq mi) is agricultural. The open areas within the built-up zone amount to 22 km^2^ (8.5 sq mi).^[\[25\]](#cite_note-25)^{#cite_ref-25}

The city of Oslo was established as a municipality on 3 January 1838 (see [formannskapsdistrikt](/wiki/Formannskapsdistrikt "Formannskapsdistrikt")). It was separated from the county of [Akershus](/wiki/Akershus "Akershus") to become a county of its own in 1842. The rural municipality of [Aker](/wiki/Aker,_Norway "Aker, Norway") was merged with Oslo on 1 January 1948 (and simultaneously transferred from Akershus county to Oslo county). Furthermore, Oslo shares several important functions with Akershus county.

Name and seal {#Name_and_seal}
------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Name and seal")\]

After being destroyed by a fire in 1624, during the reign of [King Christian IV](/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark "Christian IV of Denmark"), a new city was built closer to [Akershus Fortress](/wiki/Akershus_Fortress "Akershus Fortress") and named Christiania in the king's honour. The old site east of the Aker river was not abandoned, however, and the village of Oslo remained as a suburb outside the city gates. The suburb called Oslo was eventually included in the city proper. In 1925 the name of the suburb was [transferred](#1900–present) to the whole city, while the suburb was renamed ["Gamlebyen"](/wiki/Old_Town,_Oslo "Old Town, Oslo"), literally "the Old town", to avoid confusion.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-29)^ ^[\[30\]](#cite_note-Osloby-30)^ ^[\[31\]](#cite_note-SNL_Historie-31)^ The Old Town is an area within the administrative district [Gamle Oslo](/wiki/Gamle_Oslo "Gamle Oslo"). The previous names are reflected in street names like Oslo gate (Oslo street)^[\[32\]](#cite_note-32)^ and Oslo hospital.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-33)^{#cite_ref-33}  

### Toponymy {#Toponymy}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Toponymy")\]  
For full article, see [History of Oslo's name](/wiki/History_of_Oslo%27s_name "History of Oslo's name")

The origin of the name *Oslo* has been the subject of much debate. It is nigh-certainly derived from [Old Norse](/wiki/Old_Norse "Old Norse") and was---in all probability---originally the name of a large farm at [Bjørvika](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rvika "Bjørvika"), while the meaning of that name is disputed. Modern linguists generally interpret the original *Óslo* , *Áslo* or *Ánslo* as either "meadow at the foot of a hill" or "meadow consecrated to the [Gods](/wiki/%C3%86sir "Æsir")", with both considered equally likely.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-34)^{#cite_ref-34}

Erroneously, it was once assumed that *Oslo* meant "the mouth of the Lo river", a supposed previous name for the [river Alna](/wiki/Alnaelva "Alnaelva"). Not only has no evidence been found of a river "Lo" predating the work where [Peder Claussøn Friis](/wiki/Peder_Clauss%C3%B8n_Friis "Peder Claussøn Friis") first proposed this etymology, but the very name is ungrammatical in Norwegian: the correct form would have been *Loaros* (cf. [Nidaros](/wiki/Nidaros "Nidaros")).^[\[35\]](#cite_note-35)^ The name *Lo* is now believed to be a [back-formation](/wiki/Back-formation "Back-formation") arrived at by Friis in support of his \[idea about\] etymology for *Oslo* .^[\[36\]](#cite_note-36)^{#cite_ref-36}  

### Seal {#Seal}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Seal")\]  
Main article: [Seal of Oslo](/wiki/Seal_of_Oslo "Seal of Oslo")

Oslo is one of very few cities in Norway, besides [Bergen](/wiki/Bergen "Bergen") and [Tønsberg](/wiki/T%C3%B8nsberg "Tønsberg"), that does not have a formal [coat of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms "Coat of arms"), but which uses a city seal instead.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-37)^ The seal of Oslo shows the city's [patron saint](/wiki/Patron_saint "Patron saint"), [St. Hallvard](/wiki/Hallvard_Vebj%C3%B8rnsson "Hallvard Vebjørnsson"), with his attributes, the [millstone](/wiki/Millstone "Millstone") and [arrows](/wiki/Arrow "Arrow"), with a naked woman at his feet. He is seated on a throne with lion decorations, which at the time was also commonly used by the [Norwegian kings](/wiki/List_of_Norwegian_monarchs "List of Norwegian monarchs").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-Heraldry-38)^{#cite_ref-Heraldry_38-0}  

### Other names {#Other_names}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Other names")\]

Oslo has various nicknames and names in other languages. The city is sometimes known as "The Tiger City" ([Norwegian](/wiki/Norwegian_language "Norwegian language"): *Tigerstaden* ), probably inspired by an 1870 poem by [Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rnstjerne_Bj%C3%B8rnson "Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson") which referenced then-Christiania in central Oslo. The nickname is mostly used by Norwegians from out of town, and rarely by people from the Oslo region.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-39)^{#cite_ref-39}

------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: History")\]  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Oslo](/wiki/Timeline_of_Oslo "Timeline of Oslo").  

### The Viking Age {#The_Viking_Age}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: The Viking Age")\]

During the [Viking Age](/wiki/Viking_Age "Viking Age"), the area that includes modern Oslo was located in [Viken](/wiki/Viken,_Norway "Viken, Norway"), the northernmost province of [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark"). Control over the area shifted between Danish and Norwegian kings in the Middle Ages, and Denmark continued to claim the area until 1241.

According to the Norse [sagas](/wiki/Saga "Saga"), Oslo was founded around 1049 by [Harald Hardrada](/wiki/Harald_Hardrada "Harald Hardrada").^[\[40\]](#cite_note-40)^ Recent archaeological research, however, uncovered Christian burials which could be dated to prior to AD 1000, evidence of a preceding urban settlement.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-41)^ This called for the celebration of Oslo's millennium in 2000 rather than 2049.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-41}  

### 1000--1600 {#1000.E2.80.931600}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: 1000–1600")\]  
Main article: [Old Town, Oslo](/wiki/Old_Town,_Oslo "Old Town, Oslo")

Under the reign of [Olaf III of Norway](/wiki/Olaf_III_of_Norway "Olaf III of Norway") (1067-1093), Oslo became a cultural centre for [Eastern Norway](/wiki/Eastern_Norway "Eastern Norway"). [Hallvard Vebjørnsson](/wiki/Hallvard_Vebj%C3%B8rnsson "Hallvard Vebjørnsson") became the city's [patron saint](/wiki/Patron_saint "Patron saint") and is depicted on the city's seal.

In 1174, [Hovedøya Abbey](/wiki/Hoved%C3%B8ya_Abbey "Hovedøya Abbey") was built. The churches and abbeys became major owners of large tracts of land, which proved important for the city's economic development, especially before the Black Death.

At the end of the 12th century, [Hanseatic League](/wiki/Hanseatic_League "Hanseatic League") traders from [Rostock](/wiki/Rostock "Rostock") moved into the city and gained major influence in the city.

On 25 July 1197, [Sverre of Norway](/wiki/Sverre_of_Norway "Sverre of Norway") and his soldiers attacked Oslo from [Hovedøya](/wiki/Hoved%C3%B8ya "Hovedøya").^[\[42\]](#cite_note-AttackFromHovedøya-42)^{#cite_ref-AttackFromHovedøya_42-0}

During the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), Oslo reached new heights during the reign of [Haakon V of Norway](/wiki/Haakon_V_of_Norway "Haakon V of Norway") (1299--1319). He was the first king to reside permanently in the city, and it has been regarded as the capital city of Norway since his reign. He also started the construction of the [Akershus Fortress](/wiki/Akershus_Fortress "Akershus Fortress") and the Oslo [Kongsgård](/wiki/Kongsg%C3%A5rd "Kongsgård").

The Black Death came to Norway in 1349 and, like other cities in Europe, the city suffered greatly. The churches' earnings from their land dropped so much that the Hanseatic traders dominated the city's foreign trade in the 15th century.

In 1380, Norway was the weaker part in a [personal union](/wiki/Personal_union "Personal union") with Denmark, and Oslo's role was reduced to that of provincial administrative centre, with the monarchs residing in [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen").  

### 17th century {#17th_century}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: 17th century")\]

Over the years, fires destroyed significant parts of the city multiple times, as many of the city's buildings were built entirely of wood. After the fourteenth calamity, in 1624, which lasted for three days, [Christian IV of Denmark](/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark "Christian IV of Denmark") decided that the old city should not be rebuilt again. His men built a network of roads on the other side of the bay in Akershagen near [Akershus Castle](/wiki/Akershus_Castle "Akershus Castle"). He demanded that all citizens move their shops and workplaces to the newly built city of "Christiania", named in his honour.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-43)^ The part of the city built starting in 1624 is now often called *Kvadraturen \[[Wikidata](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Special:EntityPage/Q11982577 "d:Special:EntityPage/Q11982577")\]* because of its orthogonal layout in regular, square blocks.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-44)^ [Anatomigården](/wiki/Anatomig%C3%A5rden "Anatomigården") is a historic timber framing house located on the north side of Christiania Torv; it was built in 1640.{#cite_ref-44}

The transformation of Christiania went slowly for the first hundred years. However, outside of the city at [Vaterland](/wiki/Vaterland,_Norway "Vaterland, Norway"), [Grønland](/wiki/Gr%C3%B8nland,_Oslo "Grønland, Oslo"), and the [old town of Oslo](/wiki/Old_Town,_Oslo "Old Town, Oslo"), a new, unmanaged part of the city arose populated by citizens of lower class status.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

The last [Black Death](/wiki/Black_Death "Black Death") outbreak in Oslo occurred in 1654.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-45)^{#cite_ref-45}  

### 18th century {#18th_century}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: 18th century")\]

In the 18th century, after the [Great Northern War](/wiki/Great_Northern_War "Great Northern War"), the city's economy boomed with shipbuilding and trade. The strong economy transformed Christiania into a trading port.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

### 19th century {#19th_century}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: 19th century")\]

The Royal Frederick University (now the [University of Oslo](/wiki/University_of_Oslo "University of Oslo")) was founded in 1811; the fact that it was founded this late reportedly had an adverse effect on the development of the nation.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-46)^{#cite_ref-46}
[![Royal Palace](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Royal_Palace%2C_Oslo_%282015%29.JPG/220px-Royal_Palace%2C_Oslo_%282015%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Royal_Palace,_Oslo_(2015).JPG) Royal Palace, Oslo (2015)

In 1814 the former provincial town of Christiania became the capital of the independent Kingdom of Norway, when the union with Denmark was dissolved and replaced by a [personal union with Sweden](/wiki/Union_between_Sweden_and_Norway "Union between Sweden and Norway"). Several state institutions were established and the city's role as a capital initiated a period of rapidly increasing population. The government of this new state needed buildings for its expanding administration and institutions. Several important buildings and landmarks were erected in the 19th century, including the [Royal Palace](/wiki/Royal_Palace,_Oslo "Royal Palace, Oslo") (1825-1848), the [Stock Exchange](/wiki/Oslo_Stock_Exchange "Oslo Stock Exchange") (1826-1828), the [Bank of Norway](/wiki/Bank_of_Norway "Bank of Norway") (1828), the [Storting](/wiki/Storting "Storting") (1861-1866), the [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_(Oslo) "National Theatre (Oslo)") (1899), and several [University](/wiki/University_of_Oslo "University of Oslo") buildings. Among the world-famous artists who lived here during this period were [Henrik Ibsen](/wiki/Henrik_Ibsen "Henrik Ibsen") and [Knut Hamsun](/wiki/Knut_Hamsun "Knut Hamsun") (the latter was awarded the Nobel Prize for literature).

Large areas of the surrounding [Aker municipality](/wiki/Aker,_Norway "Aker, Norway") were incorporated in 1839, 1859, and 1878. The 1859 expansion included [Grünerløkka](/wiki/Gr%C3%BCnerl%C3%B8kka "Grünerløkka"), [Grønland](/wiki/Gr%C3%B8nland,_Oslo "Grønland, Oslo"), and [Oslo](/wiki/Old_Town,_Oslo "Old Town, Oslo"). At that time the area called *Oslo* (now *Gamlebyen* or Old Town) was a village or suburb outside the city borders east of Aker river.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-47)^ The population increased from approximately 10.000 in 1814 to 230.000 in 1900. In 1850, Christiania overtook [Bergen](/wiki/Bergen "Bergen") and became the most populous city in the country. Christiania expanded its industry from 1840, most importantly around [Akerselva](/wiki/Akerselva "Akerselva"). There was a spectacular building boom during the last decades of the 19th century, with many new apartment buildings and renewal of the city center, but the boom collapsed in 1899.{#cite_ref-47}

In 1877 the city was renamed *Kristiania*.  

### 1900--present {#1900.E2.80.93present}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: 1900–present")\]

The city and municipality used the name *Kristiania* until 1 January 1925 when the original name of *Oslo* [was restored](/wiki/Geographical_renaming "Geographical renaming").^[\[48\]](#cite_note-48)^ This was because Norway became fully independent in 1905, and Norwegians argued that a name memorializing a Danish king ([Christian IV of Denmark](/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark "Christian IV of Denmark")) was inappropriate as the name of the capital of their country.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-49)^{#cite_ref-49}

The municipality developed new areas such as [Ullevål garden city](/wiki/Ullev%C3%A5l_Hageby "Ullevål Hageby") (1918--1926) and [Torshov](/wiki/Torshov "Torshov") (1917--1925). [City Hall](/wiki/Oslo_City_Hall "Oslo City Hall") was constructed in the former slum area of [Vika](/wiki/Vika,_Oslo "Vika, Oslo") from 1931 to 1950. In 1948, Oslo merged with [Aker](/wiki/Aker,_Norway "Aker, Norway"), a municipality which surrounded the capital and was 27 times larger, thus creating the modern, vastly enlarged Oslo municipality. At the time, Aker was a mostly affluent, green suburban community, and the merger was unpopular in Aker.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-50)^ Other suburbs, such as [Lambertseter](/wiki/Lambertseter "Lambertseter"), began to be developed in the 1950s. [Aker Brygge](/wiki/Aker_Brygge "Aker Brygge") was constructed on the site of the former [shipyard](/wiki/Shipyard "Shipyard"), [Akers Mekaniske Verksted](/wiki/Aker_ASA "Aker ASA"), from 1982 to 1998.{#cite_ref-50}

Norway was [invaded by Germany](/wiki/Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung "Operation Weserübung") on 9 April 1940. Efforts to stop the invasion, most notably the [sinking of the *Blücher*](/wiki/Battle_of_Dr%C3%B8bak_Sound "Battle of Drøbak Sound"), delayed the occupation of Oslo for several hours which allowed [King Haakon](/wiki/Haakon_VII_of_Norway "Haakon VII of Norway") to escape the city. Oslo remained occupied throughout the war until Germany capitulated in 1945. During this time, the occupying troops were harried by saboteurs in acts of resistance. On 31 December 1944, allied bombers missed their intended target and hit a tram, resulting in 79 civilian deaths.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-51)^{#cite_ref-51}

During the [2011 Norway attacks](/wiki/2011_Norway_attacks "2011 Norway attacks"), Oslo was hit by a bomb blast that ripped through the [Government Quarter](/wiki/Regjeringskvartalet "Regjeringskvartalet"), damaging several buildings including the building that houses the [Office of the Prime Minister](/wiki/Office_of_the_Prime_Minister_(Norway) "Office of the Prime Minister (Norway)"). Eight people died in the bomb attack.

On 25 June 2022, two people were killed and 21 others injured in [a mass shooting](/wiki/2022_Oslo_shooting "2022 Oslo shooting"). An Iranian-born Norwegian citizen was subsequently charged with "aggravated terrorism".^[\[52\]](#cite_note-BBC_News-2022-52)^^[\[53\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}

The city has continued to expand. For a few years, new large scale housing areas and infrastructure projects are being built and planned across the city, notably in [Hasle](/wiki/Hasle,_Oslo "Hasle, Oslo"),^[\[54\]](#cite_note-54)^ [Helsfyr](/wiki/Helsfyr "Helsfyr"),^[\[55\]](#cite_note-55)^[Bjørvika](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rvika "Bjørvika"),^[\[56\]](#cite_note-56)^ [Nydalen](/wiki/Nydalen "Nydalen")^[\[57\]](#cite_note-57)^ and [Sinsen](/wiki/Sinsen "Sinsen"), this is increasing the density in and around [Ring 2](/wiki/Ring_2_(Oslo) "Ring 2 (Oslo)") and [Ring 3](/wiki/Ring_3_(Oslo) "Ring 3 (Oslo)"). The [Fornebu line](/wiki/Fornebu_Line "Fornebu Line") on the metro is under construction as of 2024, and further subway lines crossing the inner city are being planned.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Geography")\]  
See also: [Hadelandshøgda](/wiki/Hadelandsh%C3%B8gda "Hadelandshøgda") and [Oslo Graben](/wiki/Oslo_Graben "Oslo Graben")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Oslo_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/220px-Oslo_by_Sentinel-2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Oslo_by_Sentinel-2.jpg) Satellite image of Oslo, July 2018 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Tettstedet_Oslo_2005.png/300px-Tettstedet_Oslo_2005.png)](/wiki/File:Tettstedet_Oslo_2005.png) A map of the urban areas of Oslo in 2005. The grey area in the middle indicates Oslo's city centre.

Oslo occupies an arc of land at the northernmost end of the [Oslofjord](/wiki/Oslofjord "Oslofjord"). The [fjord](/wiki/Fjord "Fjord"), which is nearly bisected by the [Nesodden](/wiki/Nesodden "Nesodden") peninsula opposite Oslo, lies to the south; in all other directions Oslo is surrounded by green hills and mountains. There are 40 islands within the city limits, the largest being [Malmøya](/wiki/Malm%C3%B8ya "Malmøya") (0.56 km^2^ or 0.22 sq mi), and scores more around the Oslofjord. Oslo has 343 lakes, the largest being [Maridalsvannet](/wiki/Maridalsvannet "Maridalsvannet") (3.91 km^2^ or 1.51 sq mi). This is also a main source of drinking water for large parts of Oslo.

Although [Eastern Norway](/wiki/Eastern_Norway "Eastern Norway") has a number of rivers, none of these flow into the ocean at Oslo. Instead Oslo has two smaller rivers: [Akerselva](/wiki/Akerselva "Akerselva") (draining Maridalsvannet, which flows into the fjord in [Bjørvika](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rvika "Bjørvika")), and [Alna](/wiki/Alna_River "Alna River"). The waterfalls in Akerselva gave power to some of the first modern industry of Norway in the 1840s. Later in the century, the river became the symbol of the stable and consistent economic and social divide of the city into [an East End and a West End](/wiki/East_End_and_West_End_of_Oslo "East End and West End of Oslo"); the labourers' neighbourhoods lie on both sides of the river, and the divide in reality follows Uelands street a bit further west. River Alna flows through Groruddalen, Oslo's major suburb and industrial area. The highest point is Kirkeberget, at 629 m (2,064 ft). Although the city's population is small compared to most European capitals, it occupies an unusually large land area, of which two-thirds are [protected areas](/wiki/Protected_area "Protected area") of forests, hills and lakes. Its boundaries encompass many [parks and open areas](/wiki/Parks_and_open_spaces_in_Oslo "Parks and open spaces in Oslo"), giving it an airy and green appearance. ^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Tjuvholmen_Aker_brygge.jpg/900px-Tjuvholmen_Aker_brygge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tjuvholmen_Aker_brygge.jpg)  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Oslo has a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Dfb* )^[\[59\]](#cite_note-en.climate-data.org-59)^ or, if the original [Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate "Köppen climate") winter threshold −3 °C (27 °F) is used, an [oceanic climate](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") (*Cfb* ) bordering on a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") in the 1991--2020 base period. Oslo has some of the warmest summers of Norway and fairly cold winters.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-60)^ Oslo receives a fair amount of precipitation during the year.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-en.climate-data.org-59)^ The driest seasons are winter and spring, and the wettest are summer and autumn. Because of the city's northern latitude, daylight varies greatly, from more than 18 hours in midsummer, when it never gets completely dark at night (no darker than [nautical twilight](/wiki/Nautical_twilight "Nautical twilight")), to around 6 hours in midwinter.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-61)^{#cite_ref-61}

The warmest month on record is July 1901 with mean 22.7 °C (72.9 °F), and the all-time high 35 °C (95 °F) was also recorded in July 1901.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-62)^ The warmest month in more recent years is July 2018 with mean 22.2 °C (72.0 °F) and average daily high 29 °C (84.2 °F). The record summer of 2018 also recorded the warmest May and May all-time high with 31.1 °C (88.0 °F) on 30th, and 2018 was even the sunniest year on record with 2133 sunhours.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-63)^^[\[64\]](#cite_note-64)^^[\[65\]](#cite_note-65)^ On [27 July 2018](/wiki/2018_European_heat_wave "2018 European heat wave"), the temperature in Oslo rose to 34.6 °C (94.3 °F), the hottest recorded since 1937, when weather recordings started at Blindern. In January, on average three out of four days are below freezing (0 °C \[32 °F\]) and one out of four days is colder than −10 °C (14 °F) (1961--1990).^[\[66\]](#cite_note-met.no-66)^ The coldest temperature recorded is −29.6 °C (−21.3 °F), on 21 January 1841, while the coldest recorded at Blindern is −26 °C (−14.8 °F) in January 1941. The coldest temperature more recently was on 6 January 2024, where the temperature reached -23.1 °C (-17 °F) at Oslo-Blindern, which is the coldest measured temperature since January 1987. The coldest month on record is January 1941 and also January 1947 with mean −12.9 °C (8.8 °F) and average daily low −16.7 °C (1.9 °F). The average date for the last overnight freeze (low below 0 °C, 32.0 °F) in spring is 23 April^[\[67\]](#cite_note-67)^ and average date for first freeze in autumn is 17 October^[\[68\]](#cite_note-68)^ giving a frost-free season of 176 days (1981--2010 average for Blindern). Oslo sits right on the border between [hardiness zones](/wiki/Hardiness_zones "Hardiness zones") 7a and 7b.{#cite_ref-68}

Oslo Gardermoen airport is located 35 km northeast of Oslo and has a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") (Köppen climate classification: *Dfb* ) bordering on a [subarctic climate](/wiki/Subarctic_climate "Subarctic climate") (Köppen climate classification: *Dfc* ) in the 1991--2020 base period.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-69)^{#cite_ref-69}  
{#cite_ref-71}

Parks and recreation areas {#Parks_and_recreation_areas}
--------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Parks and recreation areas")\]  
Main article: [Parks and open spaces in Oslo](/wiki/Parks_and_open_spaces_in_Oslo "Parks and open spaces in Oslo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Oslo%2C_Vigeland_Park_%282%29.jpg/220px-Oslo%2C_Vigeland_Park_%282%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Oslo,_Vigeland_Park_(2).jpg) [Vigeland Park](/wiki/Vigeland_Park "Vigeland Park") in Oslo

Oslo has many parks and green areas within the city core, as well as outside it.

* [Frogner Park](/wiki/Frogner_Park "Frogner Park") is a large park located a few minutes' walk away from the city centre. This is the biggest and best-known park in Norway, with a large collection of sculptures by [Gustav Vigeland](/wiki/Gustav_Vigeland "Gustav Vigeland").
* [Bygdøy](/wiki/Bygd%C3%B8y "Bygdøy") is a large green area, commonly called the Museum Peninsula of Oslo. The area is surrounded by the sea and is one of the most expensive districts in Norway.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-72)^{#cite_ref-72}
* [Ekebergparken Sculpture Park](/wiki/Ekebergparken_Sculpture_Park "Ekebergparken Sculpture Park") is a sculpture park and a national heritage park with a panoramic view of the city at [Ekeberg](/wiki/Ekeberg "Ekeberg") in the southeast of the city.
* [St. Hanshaugen Park](/wiki/St._Hanshaugen_Park "St. Hanshaugen Park") is an old public park on a high hill in central Oslo. "St. Hanshaugen" is also the name of the surrounding neighbourhood as well as the larger administrative district (borough) that includes major parts of central Oslo.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-73)^{#cite_ref-73}
* [Tøyen Park](/wiki/T%C3%B8yen_Park "Tøyen Park") stretches out behind the old [Munch Museum](/wiki/Munch_Museum "Munch Museum"), and is a vast, grassy expanse. In the north, there is a lookout point known as Ola Narr. The Tøyen area also includes the [Botanical Garden](/wiki/University_Botanical_Garden_(Oslo) "University Botanical Garden (Oslo)") and Museum belonging to the University of Oslo.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-74)^{#cite_ref-74}

Oslo (with neighbouring Sandvika-Asker) is built in a horseshoe shape on the shores of the Oslofjord and limited in most directions by hills and forests. As a result, any point within the city is relatively close to the forest. There are two major forests bordering the city: *[Østmarka](/wiki/%C3%98stmarka "Østmarka")* (literally "Eastern Forest", on the eastern perimeter of the city), and the very large *[Nordmarka](/wiki/Nordmarka "Nordmarka")* (literally "Northern Forest", stretching from the northern perimeter of the city deep into the hinterland).

* [Sognsvann](/wiki/Sognsvann "Sognsvann") is a lake in Oslomarka, located at the land border, just north of Oslo. Sognsvann was drinking water for Oslo from 1876 to 1967.

The lake's altitude above sea level is 183 metres. The water is in a popular hiking area. Near the water itself, it is great for barbecues, swimming, beach volleyball and other activities.

The municipality operates eight public swimming pools.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-75)^ [Tøyenbadet](/wiki/T%C3%B8yenbadet "Tøyenbadet") is the largest indoor swimming facility in Oslo and one of the few pools in Norway offering a 50-metre main pool. Another in that size is the outdoor pool [Frognerbadet](/wiki/Frognerbadet "Frognerbadet").{#cite_ref-75}  

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/19-08-25-Oslo_Holmenkollenbakken-RalfR.jpg/190px-19-08-25-Oslo_Holmenkollenbakken-RalfR.jpg)](/wiki/File:19-08-25-Oslo_Holmenkollenbakken-RalfR.jpg)  
[Holmenkollen](/wiki/Holmenkollen "Holmenkollen") ski jump  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Bryggetorget1.JPG/190px-Bryggetorget1.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bryggetorget1.JPG)  
[Bryggetorget](https://no.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryggetorget_(Oslo) "no:Bryggetorget (Oslo)")

Oslo's cityscape is being redeveloped as a modern city with various access-points, an extensive metro-system with a new financial district and a cultural city. In 2008, an exhibition was held in London presenting the award-winning [Oslo Opera House](/wiki/Oslo_Opera_House "Oslo Opera House"), the urban regeneration scheme of Oslo's seafront, [Munch/Stenersen](/wiki/Munch/Stenersen "Munch/Stenersen") and the new Deichman Library. Most of the buildings in the city and in neighbouring communities are low in height with only the [Plaza](/wiki/Oslo_Plaza "Oslo Plaza"), [Posthuset](/wiki/Posthuset_(building) "Posthuset (building)") and the highrises at Bjørvika considerably taller.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-76)^{#cite_ref-76}  

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Architecture")\]  
See also: [Architecture of Norway](/wiki/Architecture_of_Norway "Architecture of Norway")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Fjordbyen.gif/220px-Fjordbyen.gif)](/wiki/File:Fjordbyen.gif) [Fjordbyen](/wiki/Fjordbyen "Fjordbyen") is a large construction project in the seaside of central Oslo, stretching from [Bygdøy](/wiki/Bygd%C3%B8y "Bygdøy") in the west to [Ormøya](/wiki/Orm%C3%B8ya "Ormøya") in the east. Some areas include: [Bjørvika](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rvika "Bjørvika"), [Aker brygge](/wiki/Aker_brygge "Aker brygge"), [Tjuvholmen](/wiki/Tjuvholmen "Tjuvholmen"), and the [central station](/wiki/Oslo_Central_Station "Oslo Central Station") area. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/A_window_in_Aker_Brygge%2C_Oslo_N.jpg/220px-A_window_in_Aker_Brygge%2C_Oslo_N.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_window_in_Aker_Brygge,_Oslo_N.jpg) Detail of modern architecture at [Aker Brygge](/wiki/Aker_Brygge "Aker Brygge")

Oslo's architecture is very diverse. The architect [Carl Frederik Stanley](/wiki/Carl_Frederik_Stanley "Carl Frederik Stanley") (1769--1805), who was educated in [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen"), spent some years in Norway around the turn of the 19th century. He undertook some minor commissions for wealthy patrons in and around Oslo, but his major achievement was the renovation of the [Oslo Katedralskole](/wiki/Oslo_Katedralskole "Oslo Katedralskole"), completed in 1800.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-77)^ He added a classical portico to the front of an older structure, and a semicircular auditorium that was sequestered by Parliament in 1814 as a temporary place to assemble, now preserved at [Norsk Folkemuseum](/wiki/Norsk_Folkemuseum "Norsk Folkemuseum") as a national monument.{#cite_ref-77}

When Christiania was made capital of Norway in 1814, there were practically no buildings suitable for the many new government institutions. An ambitious building program was initiated, but realised very slowly because of economic constraints. The first major undertaking was the [Royal Palace](/wiki/Royal_Palace,_Oslo "Royal Palace, Oslo"), designed by [Hans Linstow](/wiki/Hans_Linstow "Hans Linstow") and built between 1824 and 1848. Linstow also planned [Karl Johans gate](/wiki/Karl_Johans_gate "Karl Johans gate"), the avenue connecting the Palace and the city, with a monumental square halfway to be surrounded by buildings for [University](/wiki/Oslo_University "Oslo University"), the [Parliament](/wiki/Stortinget "Stortinget") (Storting) and other institutions. Only the university buildings were realised according to this plan. [Christian Heinrich Grosch](/wiki/Christian_Heinrich_Grosch "Christian Heinrich Grosch"), one of the first architects educated completely within Norway, designed the original building for the [Oslo Stock Exchange](/wiki/Oslo_Stock_Exchange "Oslo Stock Exchange") (1826--1828), the local branch of the [Bank of Norway](/wiki/Bank_of_Norway "Bank of Norway") (1828), [Christiania Theatre](/wiki/Christiania_Theatre "Christiania Theatre") (1836--1837), and the first campus for the [University of Oslo](/wiki/University_of_Oslo "University of Oslo") (1841--1856). For the university buildings, he sought the assistance of the German architect [Karl Friedrich Schinkel](/wiki/Karl_Friedrich_Schinkel "Karl Friedrich Schinkel"). German architectural influence persisted in Norway, and many wooden buildings followed the principles of [Neoclassicism](/wiki/Neoclassicism "Neoclassicism"). In Oslo, the German architect [Alexis de Chateauneuf](/wiki/Alexis_de_Chateauneuf "Alexis de Chateauneuf") designed [Trefoldighetskirken](/wiki/Trefoldighetskirken_(Oslo) "Trefoldighetskirken (Oslo)"), the first neo-gothic church, completed by von Hanno in 1858.

A number of landmark buildings, particularly in Oslo, were built in the [Functionalist](/wiki/Functionalism_(architecture) "Functionalism (architecture)") style (better known in the US and Britain as Modernist), the first being [Skansen restaurant](/w/index.php?title=Skansen_restaurant&action=edit&redlink=1 "Skansen restaurant (page does not exist)") \[[no](https://no.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skansen_restaurant "no:Skansen restaurant")\] (1925--1927) by [Lars Backer](/wiki/Lars_Backer "Lars Backer"), demolished in 1970. Backer also designed the restaurant at Ekeberg, which opened in 1929. [Kunstnernes Hus](/wiki/Kunstnernes_Hus "Kunstnernes Hus") art gallery by [Gudolf Blakstad](/wiki/Gudolf_Blakstad "Gudolf Blakstad") and [Herman Munthe-Kaas](/wiki/Herman_Munthe-Kaas "Herman Munthe-Kaas") (1930) still shows the influence of the preceding classicist trend of the 1920s. The redevelopment of [Oslo Airport](/wiki/Gardermoen "Gardermoen") (by the Aviaplan consortium) at Gardermoen, which opened in 1998, was Norway's largest construction project to date.
