{#cite_ref-x067_78-0}

Oslo is the capital of Norway, and as such is the seat of Norway's national government. Most government offices, including that of the [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Norway "Prime Minister of Norway"), are gathered at *Regjeringskvartalet* , a cluster of buildings close to the national Parliament, the [Storting](/wiki/Parliament_of_Norway "Parliament of Norway").

Constituting both a municipality and a county of Norway, the city of Oslo is represented in the Storting by twenty members of parliament. The [Conservative Party](/wiki/Conservative_Party_of_Norway "Conservative Party of Norway") is the most represented party in Oslo with five members, the [Labour Party](/wiki/Norwegian_Labour_Party "Norwegian Labour Party") has four, the [Liberals](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Norway "Liberal Party of Norway") and the [Socialist Left Party](/wiki/Socialist_Left_Party_(Norway) "Socialist Left Party (Norway)") have three each; the [Green Party](/wiki/Green_Party_(Norway) "Green Party (Norway)"), the [Red Party](/wiki/Red_Party_(Norway) "Red Party (Norway)") have two each and the [Progress Party](/wiki/Progress_Party_(Norway) "Progress Party (Norway)") has one.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-m595-79)^{#cite_ref-m595_79-0}

The combined municipality and county of Oslo has had a [parliamentary system](/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system") of government since 1986. The supreme authority of the city is the City Council (*Bystyret* ), which has 59 seats. Representatives are popularly elected every four years. The city council has five [standing committees](/wiki/Standing_committees "Standing committees"), each having its own areas of responsibility.  

### Recent elections {#Recent_elections}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Recent elections")\]

The largest parties in the City Council after the 2015-elections were the Labour Party and the Conservatives, with 20 and 19 representatives respectively. After 2015, the [city government](/wiki/Local_government "Local government") was a coalition of the Labour Party, the Green Party and the Socialist Left. With support from the Red Party, the coalition maintained a workable majority in the city council. Following the local elections of 2019, the [centre-left](/wiki/Centre-left_politics "Centre-left politics") coalition remained in government until the 2023 local elections.  

### 2023 elections {#2023_elections}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: 2023 elections")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Stortinget_-_Oslo%2C_Norway_2021-03-25_%2802%29.jpg/200px-Stortinget_-_Oslo%2C_Norway_2021-03-25_%2802%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stortinget_-_Oslo,_Norway_2021-03-25_(02).jpg)  
[Parliament of Norway](/wiki/Parliament_of_Norway "Parliament of Norway")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Raadhuset_Oslo_IMG_1403.JPG/200px-Raadhuset_Oslo_IMG_1403.JPG)](/wiki/File:Raadhuset_Oslo_IMG_1403.JPG)  
[Oslo City Hall](/wiki/Oslo_City_Hall "Oslo City Hall")

After the Conservative Party's substantial gains in the 2023 election, they formed an alliance with the Liberal Party. With confidence and support from the Christian Democrats and the Progress Party, this alliance was able to form a government.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-m595-79)^{#cite_ref-m595_79-1}

The [Mayor of Oslo](/wiki/Mayor_of_Oslo "Mayor of Oslo") chairs the city council and is the highest ranking representative of the city. Because of Oslo's parliamentary system, its mayor fulfills different needs than that of many other cities. Therefore, one of the mayor's most important roles is that of the ceremonial head of the city and its public face, similar to that of the President of the Storting at the national level. The Mayor of Oslo is Anne Lindboe.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-f643-80)^{#cite_ref-f643_80-0}

The [Governing Mayor of Oslo](/wiki/Governing_Mayor_of_Oslo "Governing Mayor of Oslo") is the head of the City government. The post was created with the implementation of parliamentarism in Oslo and is similar to the role of the prime minister at the national level. The governing mayor is [Eirik Lae Solberg](/wiki/Eirik_Lae_Solberg "Eirik Lae Solberg").^[\[79\]](#cite_note-m595-79)^{#cite_ref-m595_79-2}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Greater Oslo](/wiki/Economy_of_Greater_Oslo "Economy of Greater Oslo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Oslo_at_night.jpg/220px-Oslo_at_night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Oslo_at_night.jpg) Office buildings and apartments in [Bjørvika](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rvika "Bjørvika"), part of the redesign of former dock and industrial land in Oslo known as the [Barcode Project](/wiki/Barcode_Project "Barcode Project")

Oslo has a varied and strong economy and was ranked number one among European large cities in economic potential in the [fDi Magazine](/wiki/FDi_Magazine "FDi Magazine") report European Cities of the Future 2012.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-fdiintelligence.com-17)^ It was ranked 2nd in the category of business friendliness, behind Amsterdam.{#cite_ref-fdiintelligence.com_17-1}

Oslo is an important centre of maritime knowledge in Europe and is home to approximately 1980 companies and 8,500 employees within the maritime sector. Some of them are the world's largest shipping companies, [shipbrokers](/wiki/Shipbroker "Shipbroker"), and [insurance brokers](/wiki/Insurance_broker "Insurance broker").^[\[81\]](#cite_note-81)^ [Det Norske Veritas](/wiki/Det_Norske_Veritas "Det Norske Veritas"), headquartered at [Høvik](/wiki/H%C3%B8vik "Høvik") outside Oslo, is one of the three major maritime [classification societies](/wiki/Classification_society "Classification society") in the world, with 16.5% of the world fleet to class in its register.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-82)^ The city's port is the largest general cargo port in the country and its leading passenger gateway. Close to 6,000 ships dock at the [Port of Oslo](/wiki/Port_of_Oslo "Port of Oslo") annually with a total of 6 million tonnes of cargo and over five million passengers.{#cite_ref-82}

The [GDP](/wiki/GDP "GDP") of Oslo totaled €64 billion (€96,000 per capita) in 2016, which amounted to 20% of the national GDP.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-83)^ This compares with [NOK](/wiki/Norwegian_krone "Norwegian krone")253 billion (€23 billion) in 1995 (adjusting for 2016 inflation). The metropolitan area, bar [Moss](/wiki/Moss,_Norway "Moss, Norway") and [Drammen](/wiki/Drammen "Drammen"), contributed 25% of the national GDP in 2003 and was also responsible for more than one quarter of [tax revenues](/wiki/Tax_revenue "Tax revenue"). In comparison, total tax revenues from the oil and gas industry on the [Norwegian Continental Shelf](/wiki/Norwegian_continental_shelf "Norwegian continental shelf") amounted to about 16%.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-84)^{#cite_ref-84}

Oslo is one of the [most expensive cities](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_cities_for_expatriate_employees "List of most expensive cities for expatriate employees") in the world.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-priciest-85)^ As of 2006^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit)^, it is ranked tenth according to the Worldwide [Cost of Living](/wiki/Cost-of-living_index "Cost-of-living index") Survey provided by [Mercer Human Resource Consulting](/wiki/Mercer_Human_Resource_Consulting "Mercer Human Resource Consulting")^[\[86\]](#cite_note-86)^ and first according to the [Economist Intelligence Unit](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit") (EIU).^[\[85\]](#cite_note-priciest-85)^ The reason for this discrepancy is that the EIU omits certain factors from its final index calculation, most notably housing. In the 2015 update^[\[87\]](#cite_note-87)^ of the EIU's Worldwide Cost of Living survey, Oslo now ranks as the third most expensive city in the world.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-88)^ Although Oslo does have the most expensive [housing market](/wiki/Real_estate_economics "Real estate economics") in Norway, it is comparably cheaper than other cities on the list in that regard. Meanwhile, prices on [goods and services](/wiki/Goods_and_services "Goods and services") remain some of the highest of any city. Oslo hosts 2654 of the largest companies in Norway. Within the ranking of Europe's largest cities ordered by their number of companies Oslo is in fifth position. A whole group of oil and gas companies is situated in Oslo.{#cite_ref-88}

According to a report compiled by [Swiss bank](/wiki/Banking_in_Switzerland "Banking in Switzerland") [UBS](/wiki/UBS "UBS") in the month of August 2006,^[\[89\]](#cite_note-89)^ Oslo and London were the world's most expensive cities.{#cite_ref-89}  

Environment and decarbonization {#Environment_and_decarbonization}
------------------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Environment and decarbonization")\]

Oslo is a [compact city](/wiki/Compact_city "Compact city"). It is easy to move around by public transportation and rentable city bikes accessible to all in many places in the city centre. In 2003, Oslo received The European Sustainable City Award and in 2007 Reader's Digest ranked Oslo as number two on a list of the world's greenest, most livable cities.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-90)^^[\[91\]](#cite_note-91)^{#cite_ref-91}

The City of Oslo has set the goal of becoming a low carbon city, and reducing [greenhouse gas emissions](/wiki/Greenhouse_gas "Greenhouse gas") 95% from 1990 levels by 2030.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-92)^ The climate action plan for the Port of Oslo includes implementing a low-carbon contracting process, and installing [shore power](/wiki/Shorepower "Shorepower") for vessels which are docked.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-93)^^[\[94\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}

By October 2022, Oslo had an extensive network of bicycle lanes and tram lines, most of its ferry boats had been electrified, and the city was "on course to become the first capital city in the world with an all-electric public transport system", including e-buses.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-95)^{#cite_ref-95}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/%22Streifzug%22_mit_der_Kamera_durch_Oslo._10.jpg/220px-%22Streifzug%22_mit_der_Kamera_durch_Oslo._10.jpg)](/wiki/File:%22Streifzug%22_mit_der_Kamera_durch_Oslo._10.jpg) The faculty of Law, University of Oslo [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/BI_Norwegian_School_of_Management_Nydalen_Oslo.jpg/220px-BI_Norwegian_School_of_Management_Nydalen_Oslo.jpg)](/wiki/File:BI_Norwegian_School_of_Management_Nydalen_Oslo.jpg) BI Norwegian Business School - Oslo campus [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/UiO_004.jpg/220px-UiO_004.jpg)](/wiki/File:UiO_004.jpg) University of Oslo Library  

### Institutions of higher education {#Institutions_of_higher_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Institutions of higher education")\]

* [University of Oslo](/wiki/University_of_Oslo "University of Oslo") (Universitetet i Oslo \[UiO\])---[undergraduate](/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree "Bachelor's degree"), [graduate](/wiki/Master%27s_degree "Master's degree") and PhD programs in most fields
* [Oslo Metropolitan University](/wiki/Oslo_Metropolitan_University "Oslo Metropolitan University") (Oslomet -- Storbyuniversitetet), established 2018. Formerly [Oslo and Akershus University College of Applied Sciences](/wiki/Oslo_and_Akershus_University_College_of_Applied_Sciences "Oslo and Akershus University College of Applied Sciences") (Høgskolen i Oslo og Akershus (HiOA)) (2011--2018) and [Oslo University College](/wiki/Oslo_University_College "Oslo University College") (Høgskolen i Oslo) (1994--2011). Focuses on 3--4-year [professional degree](/wiki/First_professional_degree "First professional degree") programs.
* [BI Norwegian Business School](/wiki/BI_Norwegian_Business_School "BI Norwegian Business School") (Handelshøyskolen BI)---primarily economics and [business administration](/wiki/Management "Management"). The former college was granted a university status in 2018.
* [Kristiania University College](/wiki/Kristiania_University_College "Kristiania University College") (Høyskolen Kristiania), a merger of many smaller independent colleges in Oslo, now offers education on bachelor's master's and PhD level in a broad range of subjects.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-96)^{#cite_ref-96}
* [Oslo School of Architecture and Design](/wiki/Oslo_School_of_Architecture_and_Design "Oslo School of Architecture and Design") (Arkitektur-og designhøgskolen i Oslo \[AHO\])
* [Norwegian School of Sport Sciences](/wiki/Norwegian_School_of_Sport_Sciences "Norwegian School of Sport Sciences") (Norges idrettshøgskole \[NIH\])---offers opportunities to study at the Bachelor, Masters and Doctoral level.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-97)^{#cite_ref-97}
* [Norwegian Academy of Music](/wiki/Norwegian_Academy_of_Music "Norwegian Academy of Music") (Norges musikkhøgskole)
* [MF Norwegian School of Theology](/wiki/MF_Norwegian_School_of_Theology "MF Norwegian School of Theology") (Det teologiske Menighetsfakultet -- MF)
* [Oslo National Academy of the Arts](/wiki/Oslo_National_Academy_of_the_Arts "Oslo National Academy of the Arts") (Kunsthøgskolen i Oslo or Statens teaterhøgskole -- KHIO)^[\[98\]](#cite_note-98)^{#cite_ref-98}
* [Norwegian University of Life Sciences](/wiki/Norwegian_University_of_Life_Sciences "Norwegian University of Life Sciences") (Norges miljø- og biovitenskapelige universitet -- NMBU) located in Ås, right outside of Oslo^[\[99\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}
* [Norwegian Army Academy](/wiki/Norwegian_Military_Academy "Norwegian Military Academy") (Krigsskolen)
* Norwegian Defence University College (Forsvarets høgskole)
* Norwegian Police University College (Politihøgskolen -- PHS)
* Oslo Academy of Fine Arts (Statens kunstakademi)^[\[100\]](#cite_note-100)^{#cite_ref-100}

The level of education and productivity in the workforce is high in Norway. Nearly half of those with education at tertiary level in Norway live in the Oslo region, placing it among Europe's top three regions in relation to education. In 2008, the total workforce in the greater Oslo region (5 counties) numbered 1,020,000 people. The greater Oslo region has several higher educational institutions and is home to more than 73,000 students. The University of Oslo is the largest institution for higher education in Norway with 27,400 students and 7,028 employees in total.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-101)^{#cite_ref-101}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Culture")\]

Oslo has a large and varied number of [cultural attractions](https://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/Oslo "voy:Oslo"), which include several buildings containing artwork from [Edvard Munch](/wiki/Edvard_Munch "Edvard Munch") and various other international artists but also several [Norwegian](/wiki/Norwegian_people "Norwegian people") artists. Several world-famous writers have either lived or been born in Oslo. Examples are [Knut Hamsun](/wiki/Knut_Hamsun "Knut Hamsun") and [Henrik Ibsen](/wiki/Henrik_Ibsen "Henrik Ibsen"). The government has recently invested large amounts of money in cultural installations, facilities, buildings and festivals in the City of Oslo. [Bygdøy](/wiki/Bygd%C3%B8y "Bygdøy"), outside the city centre is the centre for history and the Norwegian Vikings' history. The area contains many parks and seasites and many museums. Examples are the [Fram Museum](/wiki/Fram_Museum "Fram Museum"), [Vikingskiphuset](/wiki/Viking_Ship_Museum_(Oslo) "Viking Ship Museum (Oslo)") and the [Kon-Tiki Museum](/wiki/Kon-Tiki_Museum "Kon-Tiki Museum"). Oslo hosts the annual Oslo Freedom Forum, a conference described by *The Economist* as "on its way to becoming a human-rights equivalent of the Davos economic forum."^[\[102\]](#cite_note-102)^ Oslo is also known for giving out the [Nobel Peace Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize "Nobel Peace Prize") every year.{#cite_ref-102}  

### Food {#Food}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Food")\]

|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| [![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg) | This section **needs expansion** . You can help by [adding to it](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=). *(August 2017)* |

Grønland, the central areas around Youngstorget and Torggata, [Karl Johans gate](/wiki/Karl_Johans_gate "Karl Johans gate") (the main pedestrian thoroughfare), [Aker Brygge](/wiki/Aker_Brygge "Aker Brygge") and [Tjuvholmen](/wiki/Tjuvholmen "Tjuvholmen"), Sørenga, and the boroughs of [Frogner](/wiki/Frogner "Frogner"), [Majorstuen](/wiki/Majorstuen "Majorstuen"), [St. Hanshaugen](/wiki/St._Hanshaugen "St. Hanshaugen") / [Bislett](/wiki/Bislett "Bislett"), and [Grünerløkka](/wiki/Gr%C3%BCnerl%C3%B8kka "Grünerløkka") all have a high concentration of cafes and restaurants. There are several food markets, the largest being Mathallen Food Hall at Vulkan with more than 30 specialty shops, cafés, and eateries.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-103)^{#cite_ref-103}

As of March 2018 six Oslo restaurants were mentioned in the [Michelin Guide](/wiki/Michelin_Guide "Michelin Guide"). [Maaemo](/wiki/Maaemo "Maaemo") is the only Norwegian restaurant ever to have been awarded three Michelin stars. Statholdergaarden, Kontrast, and Galt each have one star. Only two restaurants in Oslo have a BIB gourmand mention: Restaurant Eik and Smalhans.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-104)^{#cite_ref-104}

Due to its proximity to the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea"), fish and seafood are a staple component of cuisine in Oslo. Many restaurants also serve [game meat](/wiki/Game_meat "Game meat") year round.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-105)^{#cite_ref-105}  

### Museums, galleries {#Museums.2C_galleries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Museums, galleries")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Lambda_by_Akerselvallmenningen_and_Munchs_brygge.jpg/220px-Lambda_by_Akerselvallmenningen_and_Munchs_brygge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lambda_by_Akerselvallmenningen_and_Munchs_brygge.jpg) MUNCH Museum (2020)

Oslo houses several major museums and galleries. The [Munch Museum](/wiki/Munch_Museum "Munch Museum") contains *[The Scream](/wiki/The_Scream "The Scream")* and other works by [Edvard Munch](/wiki/Edvard_Munch "Edvard Munch"), who donated all his work to the city after his death.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-106)^ The city council is planning a new Munch Museum which is most likely to be built in [Bjørvika](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rvika "Bjørvika"), in the southeast of the city.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-autogenerated5-107)^ The museum will be named [Munch/Stenersen](/wiki/Munch/Stenersen "Munch/Stenersen").^[\[107\]](#cite_note-autogenerated5-107)^ 50 different museums are located around the city.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}

[Folkemuseet](/wiki/Norsk_Folkemuseum "Norsk Folkemuseum") is located on the [Bygdøy](/wiki/Bygd%C3%B8y "Bygdøy") peninsula and is dedicated to [Folk art](/wiki/Folk_art "Folk art"), Folk Dress, [Sami](/wiki/Sami_people "Sami people") culture and the [viking](/wiki/Viking "Viking") culture. The outdoor museum contains 155 authentic old buildings from all parts of Norway, including a [Stave Church](/wiki/Stave_Church "Stave Church").^[\[109\]](#cite_note-109)^{#cite_ref-109}

The [Vigeland Museum](/wiki/Vigeland_Museum "Vigeland Museum") located in the large [Frogner Park](/wiki/Frogner_Park "Frogner Park"), is free to access and contains over 212 sculptures by Gustav Vigeland including an obelisk and the Wheel of Life.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-110)^ Another popular sculpture is Sinnataggen, a baby boy stamping his foot in fury. This statue is very well known as an icon in the city.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-111)^ There is also a newer landscaped sculpture park, [Ekebergparken Sculpture Park](/wiki/Ekebergparken_Sculpture_Park "Ekebergparken Sculpture Park"), with works by Norwegian and international artists such as [Salvador Dalí](/wiki/Salvador_Dal%C3%AD "Salvador Dalí").^[\[112\]](#cite_note-112)^{#cite_ref-112}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Telemarkstunet_Norsk_Folkemuseum_0.jpg/220px-Telemarkstunet_Norsk_Folkemuseum_0.jpg)](/wiki/File:Telemarkstunet_Norsk_Folkemuseum_0.jpg) Historic buildings at [Norsk Folkemuseum](/wiki/Norsk_Folkemuseum "Norsk Folkemuseum")

The [Viking Ship Museum](/wiki/Viking_Ship_Museum_(Oslo) "Viking Ship Museum (Oslo)") features three [Viking ships](/wiki/Viking_ship "Viking ship") found at Oseberg, Gokstad and Tune and several other unique items from the Viking Age.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-113)^ The museum is currently closed for renovation, but will open again in 2026.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-thenorwayguide.com-2022-114)^^[\[115\]](#cite_note-115)^ The new museum will be called Museum of the Viking Age, and has plans to feature more viking items than at the old location.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-thenorwayguide.com-2022-114)^^[\[116\]](#cite_note-116)^{#cite_ref-116}

The [Oslo City Museum](/wiki/Oslo_City_Museum "Oslo City Museum") holds a permanent exhibition about the people in Oslo and the history of the city.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}

The [Kon-Tiki Museum](/wiki/Kon-Tiki_Museum "Kon-Tiki Museum") houses [Thor Heyerdahl](/wiki/Thor_Heyerdahl "Thor Heyerdahl")'s Kon-tiki and Ra II.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

The [Fram Museum](/wiki/Fram_Museum "Fram Museum") features items from arctic and antarctic expeditions, including the wooden ship [Fram](/wiki/Fram_(ship) "Fram (ship)") used by [Fritjof Nansen](/wiki/Fridtjof_Nansen "Fridtjof Nansen") and [Roald Amundsen](/wiki/Roald_Amundsen "Roald Amundsen") during their expeditions.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-119)^^[\[120\]](#cite_note-120)^{#cite_ref-120}

[The National Museum](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Art,_Architecture_and_Design "National Museum of Art, Architecture and Design") holds and preserves, exhibits and promotes public knowledge about Norway's most extensive collection of art.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-autogenerated6-121)^ The museum shows permanent exhibitions of works from its own collections but also temporary exhibitions that incorporate work loaned from elsewhere.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-autogenerated6-121)^ The National Museums exhibition avenues are the National Gallery, the Museum of Contemporary Art, the National Museum, the Museum of Decorative Arts and the National Museum of Architecture.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-autogenerated6-121)^ A new National Museum in Oslo will open in 2020 located at [Vestbanen](/wiki/Oslo_Vestbanestasjon "Oslo Vestbanestasjon") behind the [Nobel Peace Center](/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Center "Nobel Peace Center").^[\[122\]](#cite_note-122)^{#cite_ref-122}

The Nobel Peace Center is an independent organisation opened on 11 June 2005 by the [King Harald V](/wiki/King_Harald_V "King Harald V") as part of the celebrations to mark Norway's centenary as an independent country.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-autogenerated4-123)^ The building houses a permanent exhibition, expanding every year when a new [Nobel Peace Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize "Nobel Peace Prize") winner is announced, containing information of every winner in history. The building is mainly used as a communication centre.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-autogenerated4-123)^{#cite_ref-autogenerated4_123-1}  

### Music and events {#Music_and_events}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Music and events")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Am_11._Juli_2005_wurde_in_Oslo_das_Nobel_Friedenszentrum_er%C3%B6ffnet._03.jpg/220px-Am_11._Juli_2005_wurde_in_Oslo_das_Nobel_Friedenszentrum_er%C3%B6ffnet._03.jpg)](/wiki/File:Am_11._Juli_2005_wurde_in_Oslo_das_Nobel_Friedenszentrum_er%C3%B6ffnet._03.jpg) [Nobel Peace Center](/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Center "Nobel Peace Center")

Many festivals are held in Oslo, such as Oslo Jazz festival, a six-day [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") festival which has been held annually in August for the past 25 years.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-OJF-124)^ Oslo's biggest [rock](/wiki/Rock_music "Rock music") festival is Øyafestivalen or simply "Øya". It draws about 60,000 people to the [Tøyen Park](/wiki/T%C3%B8yen_Park "Tøyen Park") east in Oslo and lasts for four days.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-Øya-125)^ The Oslo International [Church Music](/wiki/Church_Music "Church Music") Festival^[\[126\]](#cite_note-126)^ has been held annually since 2000. The Oslo [World Music](/wiki/World_Music "World Music") Festival showcases people who are stars in their own country but strangers in Norway. The Oslo [Chamber Music](/wiki/Chamber_Music "Chamber Music") Festival is held in August every year and world-class chamber musicians and soloists gather in Oslo to perform at this festival. The Norwegian Wood Rock Festival is held every year in June in Oslo.{#cite_ref-126}

The [Nobel Peace Prize Ceremony](/wiki/Peace_prize "Peace prize") is headed by [the Institute](/wiki/Norwegian_Nobel_Institute "Norwegian Nobel Institute"); the award ceremony is held annually in [The City Hall](/wiki/Oslo_r%C3%A5dhus "Oslo rådhus") on 10 December.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-NobelPrize-127)^ Even though [Sami](/wiki/Sami_people "Sami people") land is far away from the capital, the Norwegian Museum of Cultural History marks the Sami National Day with a series of activities and entertainment.{#cite_ref-NobelPrize_127-0}

The World Cup Biathlon in [Holmenkollen](/wiki/Holmenkollen "Holmenkollen") is held every year and here male and female competitors compete against each other in Sprint, Pursuit and Mass Start disciplines.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-Biathlon-128)^{#cite_ref-Biathlon_128-0}

Other examples of annual events in Oslo are Desucon, a convention focusing on Japanese culture^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Desucon-129)^ and [Færderseilasen](/wiki/F%C3%A6rderseilasen "Færderseilasen"), the world's largest overnight regatta with more than 1100 boats taking part every year.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-Færderseilasen-130)^{#cite_ref-Færderseilasen_130-0}

[Rikard Nordraak](/wiki/Rikard_Nordraak "Rikard Nordraak"), composer of the [national anthem of Norway](/wiki/National_anthem_of_Norway "National anthem of Norway"), was born in Oslo in 1842.

Norway's principal orchestra is the [Oslo Philharmonic](/wiki/Oslo_Philharmonic "Oslo Philharmonic"), based at the [Oslo Concert Hall](/wiki/Oslo_Concert_Hall "Oslo Concert Hall") since 1977. Although it was founded in 1919, the Oslo Philharmonic can trace its roots to the founding of the *Christiania Musikerforening* (Christiania Musicians Society) by [Edvard Grieg](/wiki/Edvard_Grieg "Edvard Grieg") and [Johan Svendsen](/wiki/Johan_Svendsen "Johan Svendsen") in 1879.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Oslo-Filharmonien-131)^{#cite_ref-Oslo-Filharmonien_131-0}

Oslo has hosted the [Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest "Eurovision Song Contest") twice, in [1996](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_1996 "Eurovision Song Contest 1996") and [2010](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2010 "Eurovision Song Contest 2010").  

### Performing arts {#Performing_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Performing arts")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Employees_of_the_Oslo_Opera_begin_arriving_at_work.jpg/220px-Employees_of_the_Oslo_Opera_begin_arriving_at_work.jpg)](/wiki/File:Employees_of_the_Oslo_Opera_begin_arriving_at_work.jpg) [Oslo Opera House](/wiki/Oslo_Opera_House "Oslo Opera House") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Nationaltheatret_Oslo_Front_at_Night.jpg/220px-Nationaltheatret_Oslo_Front_at_Night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nationaltheatret_Oslo_Front_at_Night.jpg) The National Theatre is the largest theatre in Norway.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-autogenerated3-132)^

Oslo houses over 20 theatres, such as the Norwegian Theatre and the [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_(Oslo) "National Theatre (Oslo)") located at Karl Johan Street. The [National Theatre](/wiki/National_Theatre_(Oslo) "National Theatre (Oslo)") is the largest theatre in Norway and is situated between the royal palace and the parliament building, [Stortinget](/wiki/Stortinget "Stortinget").^[\[132\]](#cite_note-autogenerated3-132)^ The names of [Ludvig Holberg](/wiki/Ludvig_Holberg "Ludvig Holberg"), [Henrik Ibsen](/wiki/Henrik_Ibsen "Henrik Ibsen") and [Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rnstjerne_Bj%C3%B8rnson "Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson") are engraved on the façade of the building over the main entrance. This theatre represents the actors and play-writers of the country but the songwriters, singers and dancers are represented in the form of a newly opened [Oslo Opera House](/wiki/Oslo_Opera_House "Oslo Opera House"), situated in [Bjørvika](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rvika "Bjørvika"). The Opera was opened in 2008 and is a national landmark, designed by the Norwegian architectural firm, [Snøhetta](/wiki/Sn%C3%B8hetta_(company) "Snøhetta (company)"). There are two houses, together containing over 2000 seats. The building cost 500 million euro to build and took five years to build and is known for being the first [Opera House](/wiki/Opera_House "Opera House") in the world to let people walk on the roof of the building. The foyer and the roof are also used for concerts as well as the three stages.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-133)^{#cite_ref-133}  

### Literature {#Literature}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Literature")\]

Most great Norwegian authors have lived in Oslo for some period in their life. For instance, [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature")-winning author [Sigrid Undset](/wiki/Sigrid_Undset "Sigrid Undset") grew up in Oslo, and described her life there in the autobiographical novel *Elleve år* (1934; translated as *The Longest Years*; New York 1971).

The playwright [Henrik Ibsen](/wiki/Henrik_Ibsen "Henrik Ibsen") is probably the most famous Norwegian author. Ibsen wrote plays such as *[Hedda Gabler](/wiki/Hedda_Gabler "Hedda Gabler")* , *[Peer Gynt](/wiki/Peer_Gynt "Peer Gynt")* , *[A Doll's House](/wiki/A_Doll%27s_House "A Doll's House")* and *[The Lady from the Sea](/wiki/The_Lady_from_the_Sea "The Lady from the Sea")* . The [Ibsen Quotes](/wiki/Ibsen_quotes,_Oslo "Ibsen quotes, Oslo") project completed in 2008 is a work of art consisting of 69 Ibsen quotations in stainless steel lettering which have been set into the granite sidewalks of the city's central streets.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-okland-134)^{#cite_ref-okland_134-0}

In recent years, novelists like [Lars Saabye Christensen](/wiki/Lars_Saabye_Christensen "Lars Saabye Christensen"), [Tove Nilsen](/wiki/Tove_Nilsen "Tove Nilsen"), [Suresh Chandra Shukla](/w/index.php?title=Suresh_Chandra_Shukla&action=edit&redlink=1 "Suresh Chandra Shukla (page does not exist)"), [Jo Nesbø](/wiki/Jo_Nesb%C3%B8 "Jo Nesbø") and [Roy Jacobsen](/wiki/Roy_Jacobsen "Roy Jacobsen") have described the city and its people in their novels. Early 20th-century literature from Oslo include poets [Rudolf Nilsen](/wiki/Rudolf_Nilsen "Rudolf Nilsen") and [André Bjerke](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Bjerke "André Bjerke").  

### Media {#Media}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Media")\]

The newspapers *[Aftenposten](/wiki/Aftenposten "Aftenposten"), *[Dagbladet](/wiki/Dagbladet "Dagbladet")*, [Verdens Gang](/wiki/Verdens_Gang "Verdens Gang"), [Dagens Næringsliv](/wiki/Dagens_N%C3%A6ringsliv "Dagens Næringsliv")*, *[Finansavisen](/wiki/Finansavisen "Finansavisen")* , *[Dagsavisen](/wiki/Dagsavisen "Dagsavisen")*, *[Morgenbladet](/wiki/Morgenbladet "Morgenbladet")* , *[Vårt Land](/wiki/V%C3%A5rt_Land_(Norwegian_newspaper) "Vårt Land (Norwegian newspaper)"), [Nationen](/wiki/Nationen "Nationen") and [Klassekampen](/wiki/Klassekampen "Klassekampen")* are published in Oslo. The main office of the national broadcasting company [NRK](/wiki/Norwegian_Broadcasting_Corporation "Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation") is located at [Marienlyst](/wiki/Marienlyst "Marienlyst") in Oslo, near [Majorstuen](/wiki/Majorstuen "Majorstuen"), and NRK also has regional services via both radio and television. [TVNorge](/wiki/TVNorge "TVNorge") (TVNorway) is also located in Oslo, while [TV 2](/wiki/TV_2_(Norway) "TV 2 (Norway)") (based in [Bergen](/wiki/Bergen "Bergen")) and [TV3](/wiki/TV3_(Norway) "TV3 (Norway)") (based in London) operate branch offices in central Oslo. There is also a variety of specialty publications and smaller media companies. A number of magazines are produced in Oslo. The two dominant companies are [Aller Media](/wiki/Aller_Media "Aller Media") and [Hjemmet Mortensen AB](/wiki/Hjemmet_Mortensen_AB "Hjemmet Mortensen AB").  

### Sports {#Sports}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Sports")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/LIverpool_VS_Lyn_Bislett_Stadion.jpg/220px-LIverpool_VS_Lyn_Bislett_Stadion.jpg)](/wiki/File:LIverpool_VS_Lyn_Bislett_Stadion.jpg) [Bislett Stadium](/wiki/Bislett_Stadium "Bislett Stadium") during a friendly between [Lyn Oslo](/wiki/Lyn_Oslo "Lyn Oslo") and [Liverpool F.C.](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C. "Liverpool F.C.")

Oslo is home to the [Holmenkollen National Arena](/wiki/Holmenkollen_National_Arena "Holmenkollen National Arena") and [Holmenkollbakken](/wiki/Holmenkollbakken "Holmenkollbakken"), the country's main [biathlon](/wiki/Biathlon "Biathlon") and [Nordic skiing](/wiki/Nordic_skiing "Nordic skiing") venues. It hosts annual world cup tournaments, including the [Holmenkollen Ski Festival](/wiki/Holmenkollen_Ski_Festival "Holmenkollen Ski Festival"). Oslo hosted the [Biathlon World Championships](/wiki/Biathlon_World_Championships "Biathlon World Championships") in [1986](/wiki/Biathlon_World_Championships_1986 "Biathlon World Championships 1986"), [1990](/wiki/Biathlon_World_Championships_1990 "Biathlon World Championships 1990"), [2000](/wiki/Biathlon_World_Championships_2000 "Biathlon World Championships 2000"), [2002](/wiki/Biathlon_World_Championships_2002 "Biathlon World Championships 2002") and [2016](/wiki/Biathlon_World_Championships_2016 "Biathlon World Championships 2016"). [FIS Nordic World Ski Championships](/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships") have been hosted in [1930](/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships_1930 "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1930"), [1966](/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships_1966 "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1966"), [1982](/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships_1982 "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1982") and [2011](/wiki/FIS_Nordic_World_Ski_Championships_2011 "FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2011"), as well as the [1952 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1952_Winter_Olympics "1952 Winter Olympics").

Oslo is the home of several football clubs in the [Norwegian league system](/wiki/Norwegian_football_league_system "Norwegian football league system"). [Vålerenga](/wiki/V%C3%A5lerenga_Fotball "Vålerenga Fotball"), [Lyn](/wiki/FK_Lyn "FK Lyn") and [Skeid](/wiki/Skeid_Fotball "Skeid Fotball") have won both the [league](/wiki/Norwegian_Premier_League "Norwegian Premier League") and the [cup](/wiki/Norwegian_Football_Cup "Norwegian Football Cup"), [KFUM-Kameratene](/wiki/KFUM-Kameratene_Oslo "KFUM-Kameratene Oslo") entered the [top division](/wiki/Eliteserien "Eliteserien") in 2024. while Mercantile SFK and [Frigg](/wiki/Frigg_Oslo_FK "Frigg Oslo FK") have won the cup.

[Ullevål Stadion](/wiki/Ullev%C3%A5l_Stadion "Ullevål Stadion") is the home arena for the [Norway national team](/wiki/Norwegian_national_football_team "Norwegian national football team") and the [Football Cup Final](/wiki/Norwegian_Football_Cup "Norwegian Football Cup"). The stadium has previously hosted the finals of the [UEFA Women's Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Women%27s_Championship "UEFA Women's Championship") in [1987](/wiki/1987_European_Competition_for_Women%27s_Football "1987 European Competition for Women's Football") and [1997](/wiki/UEFA_Women%27s_Euro_1997 "UEFA Women's Euro 1997"), and the [2002 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship](/wiki/2002_UEFA_European_Under-19_Football_Championship "2002 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship").^[\[135\]](#cite_note-historikk-135)^ [Røa IL](/wiki/R%C3%B8a_IL "Røa IL") is Oslo's only team in the women's league, [Toppserien](/wiki/Toppserien "Toppserien"). Each year, the international youth football tournament [Norway Cup](/wiki/Norway_Cup "Norway Cup") is held on [Ekebergsletta](/wiki/Ekebergsletta "Ekebergsletta") and other places in the city.{#cite_ref-historikk_135-0}

Due to the cold climate and proximity to major forests bordering the city, skiing is a popular recreational activity in Oslo. The [Tryvann Ski Resort](/wiki/Tryvann_Ski_Resort "Tryvann Ski Resort") is the most used ski resort in Norway.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-obl1-136)^ The most successful [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") team in Norway, [Vålerenga Ishockey](/wiki/V%C3%A5lerenga_Ishockey "Vålerenga Ishockey"), is based in Oslo. [Manglerud Star](/wiki/Manglerud_Star "Manglerud Star") is another Oslo-team who play in the [top league](/wiki/GET-ligaen "GET-ligaen").{#cite_ref-obl1_136-0}

[Bislett Stadium](/wiki/Bislett_Stadium "Bislett Stadium") is the city's main track and field venue, and hosts the annual [Bislett Games](/wiki/Bislett_Games "Bislett Games"), part of [Diamond League](/wiki/Diamond_League "Diamond League"). [Bjerke Travbane](/wiki/Bjerke_Travbane "Bjerke Travbane") is the main venue for [harness racing](/wiki/Harness_racing "Harness racing") in the country. [Oslo Spektrum](/wiki/Oslo_Spektrum "Oslo Spektrum") is used for large [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") and [handball](/wiki/Team_handball "Team handball") matches. [Nordstrand HE](/wiki/Nordstrand_IF "Nordstrand IF") and [Oppsal IF](/wiki/Oppsal_IF "Oppsal IF") plays in the women's [GRUNDIGligaen](/wiki/GRUNDIGligaen_(women) "GRUNDIGligaen (women)") in handball, while [Bækkelaget HE](/wiki/B%C3%A6kkelagets_SK "Bækkelagets SK") plays in the [men's league](/wiki/GRUNDIGligaen "GRUNDIGligaen"). [Jordal Amfi](/wiki/Jordal_Amfi "Jordal Amfi"), the home of the ice hockey team [Vålerenga Ishockey](/wiki/V%C3%A5lerenga_Ishockey "Vålerenga Ishockey"), and the [national team](/wiki/Norway_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "Norway men's national ice hockey team"). The [1999 IIHF World Championship](/wiki/1999_IIHF_World_Championship "1999 IIHF World Championship") in ice hockey were held in Oslo, as have three [Bandy World Championships](/wiki/Bandy_World_Championship "Bandy World Championship"), in [1961](/wiki/1961_Bandy_World_Championship "1961 Bandy World Championship"), [1977](/wiki/1977_Bandy_World_Championship "1977 Bandy World Championship") and [1985](/wiki/1985_Bandy_World_Championship "1985 Bandy World Championship"). The [UCI Road World Championships](/wiki/UCI_Road_World_Championships "UCI Road World Championships") in [bicycle road racing](/wiki/Bicycle_road_racing "Bicycle road racing") were hosted [1993](/wiki/1993_UCI_Road_World_Championships "1993 UCI Road World Championships").

Oslo is also home to the [Oslo Pretenders Sportsklubb](/wiki/Oslo_Pretenders_Sportsklubb "Oslo Pretenders Sportsklubb"), a club that hosts a [baseball](/wiki/Baseball "Baseball"), [softball](/wiki/Softball "Softball"), [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), and [disc golf](/wiki/Disc_golf "Disc golf") teams. The baseball team has won 21 Norwegian Cup Championships and 18 Norwegian Baseball League titles. They participate in the [European Cup](/wiki/European_Cup_(baseball) "European Cup (baseball)").^[\[137\]](#cite_note-137)^{#cite_ref-137}

Oslo was [bidding](/wiki/Oslo_bid_for_the_2022_Winter_Olympics "Oslo bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics") to host the [2022 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics "2022 Winter Olympics"), but later withdrew on 2 October 2014.  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Tourism")\]

In 2018 Oslo is named one of Lonely Planet's Top Ten Cities. The travel guide's best-selling yearbook Best in Travel has selected Oslo as one of the ten best cities in the world to visit in 2018, citing the Norwegian capital's "innovative architecture and unmissable museums alongside cool bars, bistros and cafés".^[\[138\]](#cite_note-138)^{#cite_ref-138}  

Crime {#Crime}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Crime")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Norges_H%C3%B8yesterett_Supreme_Court_of_Norway.jpg/220px-Norges_H%C3%B8yesterett_Supreme_Court_of_Norway.jpg)](/wiki/File:Norges_H%C3%B8yesterett_Supreme_Court_of_Norway.jpg) Norway Supreme Court

Oslo is commonly regarded as one of the safest capitals in Europe.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-139)^^[\[140\]](#cite_note-140)^ The [Oslo Police District](/wiki/Oslo_Police_District "Oslo Police District") received 72,102 reported crimes in 2020, and crime is generally on the decrease in the city.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-141)^^[\[142\]](#cite_note-www.faktisk.no-2022-142)^ The category of reported crime that's decreasing the quickest in Oslo is property theft.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-www.faktisk.no-2022-142)^ 11.6% of all crimes in Norway are reported to be within Oslo's six central boroughs, as of 2020.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-143)^{#cite_ref-143}  

### Police {#Police}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Police")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Gr%C3%B8nlandsleiret_44_%E2%80%93_Gr%C3%B8nland_politistasjon_%2821._oktober_2018%29.jpg/220px-Gr%C3%B8nlandsleiret_44_%E2%80%93_Gr%C3%B8nland_politistasjon_%2821._oktober_2018%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gr%C3%B8nlandsleiret_44_%E2%80%93_Gr%C3%B8nland_politistasjon_(21._oktober_2018).jpg) Grønland police station

[Oslo Police District](/wiki/Oslo_Police_District "Oslo Police District") is Norway's largest police district with over 2,300 employees. Over 1,700 of those are police officers, nearly 140 police lawyers and 500 civilian employees. Oslo Police District has five police stations located around the city at Grønland, Sentrum, Stovner, Majorstuen and Manglerud. The [National Criminal Investigation Service](/wiki/National_Criminal_Investigation_Service_(Norway) "National Criminal Investigation Service (Norway)") is located in Oslo, which is a Norwegian special police division under the [NMJP](/wiki/Norwegian_Ministry_of_Justice_and_the_Police "Norwegian Ministry of Justice and the Police"). [PST](/wiki/Politiets_sikkerhetstjeneste "Politiets sikkerhetstjeneste") is also located in the Oslo District. PST is a security agency which was established in 1936 and is one of the non-secret agencies in Norway.  

### Terrorist attacks {#Terrorist_attacks}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Terrorist attacks")\]  
Main articles: [2011 Norway attacks](/wiki/2011_Norway_attacks "2011 Norway attacks") and [2022 Oslo shooting](/wiki/2022_Oslo_shooting "2022 Oslo shooting")

* One part of the [2011 Norway attacks](/wiki/2011_Norway_attacks "2011 Norway attacks") occurred within the Oslo centre on 22 July 2011. The [Oslo government offices](/wiki/Regjeringskvartalet "Regjeringskvartalet") were bombed by a [neo-Nazi](/wiki/Neo-Nazi "Neo-Nazi") with political motives.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-144)^{#cite_ref-144}
* The [2022 Oslo shooting](/wiki/2022_Oslo_shooting "2022 Oslo shooting") happened on 25 June 2022. The attack was a shooting at a pub known to be associated with the queer environment of Oslo, and the attack was targeted towards the [LGBTQ movement](/wiki/LGBT_movements "LGBT movements"). Two people were killed, and a further 21 injured.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-145)^ Due to safety concerns, the [pride parade](/wiki/Pride_parade "Pride parade") in Oslo planned for 26 June was quickly cancelled.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-146)^{#cite_ref-146}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Oslo_S_aerial.jpg/194px-Oslo_S_aerial.jpg)](/wiki/File:Oslo_S_aerial.jpg) [Oslo Central Station](/wiki/Oslo_S "Oslo S")  

### Public transport {#Public_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Public transport")\]

Oslo has Norway's most extensive public transport system, managed by [Ruter](/wiki/Ruter "Ruter").^[\[147\]](#cite_note-147)^ This includes the five-line [Oslo Metro](/wiki/Oslo_Metro "Oslo Metro"),^[\[148\]](#cite_note-148)^ the world's most extensive metro per resident; the six-line [Oslo Tramway](/wiki/Trams_in_Oslo "Trams in Oslo");^[\[149\]](#cite_note-149)^ and the eight-line [Oslo Commuter Rail](/wiki/Oslo_Commuter_Rail "Oslo Commuter Rail").^[\[150\]](#cite_note-150)^ The tramway operates within the areas close to the city centre, while the metro, which runs underground through the city centre, operates to suburbs further away; this includes two lines that operate to Bærum, and the [Ring Line](/wiki/Ring_Line_(Oslo) "Ring Line (Oslo)") which loops to areas north of the centre.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-151)^ Oslo is also covered by a bus network consisting of 52 city lines, as well as regional buses to the neighboring county of Akershus.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-152)^{#cite_ref-152}

[Oslo Central Station](/wiki/Oslo_Central_Station "Oslo Central Station") acts as the central hub,^[\[153\]](#cite_note-romplan-153)^ and offers rail services to most major cities in southern Norway as well as [Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm") and [Gothenburg](/wiki/Gothenburg "Gothenburg") in Sweden.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-154)^ The [Airport Express Train](/wiki/Flytoget "Flytoget") operates along the high-speed [Gardermoen Line](/wiki/Gardermoen_Line "Gardermoen Line"). The [Drammen Line](/wiki/Drammen_Line "Drammen Line") runs under the city centre in the [Oslo Tunnel](/wiki/Oslo_Tunnel "Oslo Tunnel").^[\[155\]](#cite_note-155)^ Some of the city islands and the neighbouring municipality of [Nesodden](/wiki/Nesodden "Nesodden") are connected by ferry.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-156)^ Daily [cruiseferry](/wiki/Cruiseferry "Cruiseferry") services operate to [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen") and [Frederikshavn](/wiki/Frederikshavn "Frederikshavn") in Denmark, and to [Kiel](/wiki/Kiel "Kiel") in Germany.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-157)^{#cite_ref-157}

The main airport serving Oslo is [Gardermoen Airport](/wiki/Oslo_Airport,_Gardermoen "Oslo Airport, Gardermoen"), located in [Ullensaker](/wiki/Ullensaker "Ullensaker"), 47 km (29 mi) from the city centre of Oslo.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-158)^ It acts as the main international gateway to Norway,^[\[159\]](#cite_note-stat2010-159)^ and is, as of 2021, ranked as the 23rd [busiest airport in Europe](/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Europe "List of the busiest airports in Europe").^[\[160\]](#cite_note-160)^ Gardermoen is a hub for [Scandinavian Airlines](/wiki/Scandinavian_Airlines "Scandinavian Airlines"), [Norwegian Air Shuttle](/wiki/Norwegian_Air_Shuttle "Norwegian Air Shuttle") and [Widerøe](/wiki/Wider%C3%B8e "Widerøe"). Oslo is also served by a secondary airport, [Torp Airport](/wiki/Sandefjord_Airport,_Torp "Sandefjord Airport, Torp"), 110 km (68 mi) from the city,^[\[161\]](#cite_note-161)^ which serves some [low-cost carriers](/wiki/Low-cost_carriers "Low-cost carriers").{#cite_ref-161}  

### Roads and automobiles {#Roads_and_automobiles}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Roads and automobiles")\]

Many of the motorways pass through the downtown and other parts of the city in tunnels. The construction of the roads is partially supported through a [toll ring](/wiki/Toll_road "Toll road").^[\[162\]](#cite_note-162)^ The major motorways through Oslo are [European Route E6](/wiki/European_route_E6 "European route E6") and [E18](/wiki/European_route_E18 "European route E18"). There are three [ring roads](/wiki/Ring_road "Ring road") in Oslo; the innermost 2 being city streets and the outermost, [Ring 3](/wiki/Ring_3_(Oslo) "Ring 3 (Oslo)"), being an [expressway](/wiki/Limited-access_road "Limited-access road").^[\[163\]](#cite_note-163)^^[\[164\]](#cite_note-164)^{#cite_ref-164}

Oslo has made an effort since the late 2000s in restricting private car use, as well promoting the use of [electric vehicles](/wiki/Electric_vehicle "Electric vehicle") above fossil-fueled vehicles. In 2018, Oslo banned all non-resident cars from its downtown areas.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-Jones-2018-165)^^[\[166\]](#cite_note-166)^ Oslo has been called the electric vehicle capital of the world, as 41% of all registered cars in the municipality are fully electric.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-Crosse-2018-167)^ ^[\[168\]](#cite_note-168)^ In September 2021, the number of electric vehicles entering Oslo's toll ring was higher than the number of fossil-fueled vehicles.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-169)^ The high amount of electric vehicles in Oslo can be attributed to cheaper tolls, no vehicle import tax, no [VAT](/wiki/VAT "VAT"), free parking, and access to [bus lanes](/wiki/Bus_lane "Bus lane") throughout the city.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-170)^^[\[167\]](#cite_note-Crosse-2018-167)^{#cite_ref-Crosse-2018_167-1}

{#cite_ref-173}

The population of Oslo was by 2010 increasing at a record rate of nearly 2% annually (17% over the last 10 years), making it the fastest-growing Scandinavian capital.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-174)^ In 2015, according to [Statistics Norway](/wiki/Statistics_Norway "Statistics Norway") annual report, there were 647,676 permanent residents in the Oslo municipality, of which 628,719 resided in the city proper. There were also 1,019,451 in the city's urban area^[\[3\]](#cite_note-Stats2015_b-3)^^[\[171\]](#cite_note-Stats2015_a-171)^^[\[175\]](#cite_note-OneMil-175)^ and an estimated 1,710,000 in the Greater Oslo Region, within 100 km (62 mi) of the city centre.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-regjeringen2010-15)^{#cite_ref-regjeringen2010_15-1}

According to the most recent census 432,000 Oslo residents (70.4% of the population) were ethnically Norwegian, an increase of 6% since 2002 (409,000).^[\[176\]](#cite_note-176)^ Oslo has the largest population of immigrants and Norwegians born to immigrant parents in Norway, both in relative and absolute figures. Of Oslo's 624,000 inhabitants, 189,400 were immigrants or born to immigrant parents, representing 30.4 percent of the capital's population. All suburbs in Oslo were above the national average of 14.1 percent. The suburbs with the highest proportions of people of immigrant origin were Søndre Nordstrand, Stovner and Alna, where they formed around 50 percent of the population.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-177)^{#cite_ref-177}

[Pakistanis](/wiki/Pakistani_Norwegians "Pakistani Norwegians") make up the single largest [ethnic minority](/wiki/Ethnic_minority "Ethnic minority"), followed by [Poles](/wiki/Polish_people "Polish people"), [Somalis](/wiki/Somali_people "Somali people"), and [Swedes](/wiki/Swedes "Swedes"). Other large immigrant groups are people from [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka"), [Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnamese_Norwegians "Vietnamese Norwegians"), [Turkey](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey"), [Morocco](/wiki/Morocco "Morocco"), [Iraq](/wiki/Iraqi_Norwegian "Iraqi Norwegian") \& [Kurdistan region](/wiki/Iraqi_Kurdistan "Iraqi Kurdistan") and [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran") \& [Kordestan province](/wiki/Kordestan_province "Kordestan province").^[\[178\]](#cite_note-178)^^[\[179\]](#cite_note-179)^^[\[180\]](#cite_note-180)^^[\[181\]](#cite_note-181)^{#cite_ref-181}

In 2013, 40% of Oslo's primary school pupils were registered as having a [first language](/wiki/First_language "First language") other than Norwegian or [Sami](/wiki/Sami_languages "Sami languages").^[\[182\]](#cite_note-182)^ The western part of the city is predominantly ethnic Norwegian, with several schools having less than 5% pupils with an immigrant background.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The eastern part of Oslo is more mixed, with some schools up to 97% of immigrant background.In the borough of [Groruddalen](/wiki/Grorud_Valley "Grorud Valley") in 2008 for instance, the ethnic Norwegian population decreased by 1,500, while the immigrant population increased by 1,600.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-183)^{#cite_ref-183}

As of 2022, immigrants of non-Western origin and their children enumerated 164,824, and made up an estimated 24% of Oslo's population.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-:0-184)^^[\[185\]](#cite_note-:1-185)^{#cite_ref-:1_185-0}

Immigrants of Western origin and their children enumerated 71,858, and made up an estimated 10% of the city's population. Immigrants made up a total of 35% of Oslo's population in 2022.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-:0-184)^^[\[185\]](#cite_note-:1-185)^^[\[186\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}  
{#cite_ref-oslo_population_188-0}

| Religion in Oslo (1 January 2019)^[\[187\]](#cite_note-oslo_medlemmar-187)^^[\[188\]](#cite_note-oslo_population-188)^ |||||
|---|---|---|---|---|
| religion ||   | percent ||
| [Church of Norway](/wiki/Church_of_Norway "Church of Norway") ||   | 48.7% ||
| Other Christian denominations ||   | 8.4% ||
| [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam") ||   | 9.5% ||
| [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism") ||   | 0.6% ||
| Other religions ||   | 1.1% ||
| Life stance communities ||   | 2.8% ||
| Unaffiliated ||   | 28.9% ||

Oslo has numerous religious communities. In 2019, 48.7% of the population were members of the [Church of Norway](/wiki/Church_of_Norway "Church of Norway"), lower than the national average of 69.9%.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-189)^ Members of other Christian denominations make up 8.4% of the population. Islam was followed by 9.5%^[\[190\]](#cite_note-190)^ and Buddhism by 0.6% of the population. Adherents of other religions formed 1.1% of the population. Life stance communities, mainly the [Norwegian Humanist Association](/wiki/Norwegian_Humanist_Association "Norwegian Humanist Association"), were represented by 2.8% of the population. 28.9% of the Oslo population were unaffiliated with any religion or life stance community.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-oslo_medlemmar-187)^^[\[188\]](#cite_note-oslo_population-188)^{#cite_ref-oslo_population_188-1}

International relations {#International_relations}
--------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: International relations")\]

Oslo is a pilot city of the [Council of Europe](/wiki/Council_of_Europe "Council of Europe") and the [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission")'s *Intercultural cities* programme, along with a number of other European cities.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-204)^^[\[205\]](#cite_note-205)^{#cite_ref-205}  

### Twin towns -- sister cities {#Twin_towns_.E2.80.93_sister_cities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Twin towns – sister cities")\]  
See also: [List of twin towns and sister cities in Norway](/wiki/List_of_twin_towns_and_sister_cities_in_Norway "List of twin towns and sister cities in Norway")

Oslo was formerly twinned with [Madison](/wiki/Madison,_Wisconsin "Madison, Wisconsin"), [Tel Aviv](/wiki/Tel_Aviv "Tel Aviv") and [Vilnius](/wiki/Vilnius "Vilnius"), but has since abolished the concept of twin cities.

### Christmas trees as gifts {#Christmas_trees_as_gifts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oslo&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Christmas trees as gifts")\]

Oslo has a tradition of sending a [Christmas tree](/wiki/Christmas_tree "Christmas tree") every year to the cities of [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."); [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"); [London](/wiki/London "London"); [Edinburgh](/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh"); [Rotterdam](/wiki/Rotterdam "Rotterdam"); [Antwerp](/wiki/Antwerp "Antwerp") and [Reykjavík](/wiki/Reykjav%C3%ADk "Reykjavík").^[\[207\]](#cite_note-207)^ Since 1947, Oslo has sent a 65-to-80 ft-high (20-to-24 m), 50 to 100-year-old [spruce](/wiki/Norway_Spruce "Norway Spruce"), as an expression of gratitude toward Britain for its support of Norway during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").^[\[208\]](#cite_note-208)^^[\[209\]](#cite_note-209)^{#cite_ref-209}
